author: WSBankrupt
body:
5G is going to be pushed hard.  I've done a fair bit of research on tickers that are worthwhile if it blows up as much as I think it will.  The implementation of these mesh networks could be huge for many companies.

Network Implementation - NOK and ERIC (Would grab NOK asap)

Base Station Chipsets - MRVL

Phone Semis - QCOM

Industrial + Vehicle Semis - NXPI

Shared Comms Infrastructure - AMT

Multi Discipline - INTC

&#x200B;

I hold positions (leaps or stonks in almost all of the above)

author: kamikazi3728
body:
In no particular order

CCI (cell site properties)

COMM (panel antennas)

AMT (cell site properties)

FIVG (5G ETF)

SBAC (cell site properties)

QCOM (its Qualcomm, need you know more?)

NXPI (semiconductors)

author: AFCheatCode
body: Tailed those huge NXPI and TXN sweeps today. Now I’m rich

author: dtdude87
body:
So I typically buy OOM calls ($60) 1-2 weeks before ER and have never not turned a decent profit.  Was up 1000% a couple quarters ago.

But - don’t hold through ER.  It’s usually a dud.

This is typically their best quarter as it’s their year end so their sales team really pushes hard to close deals, but given the fact every company out there halted spending, I doubt it’ll be good.

I work very closely with a lot of Orcl folks as well and they’ve told me they’ve cut costs heavily and aren’t allowing OT for their tech folks, which to me is a sign of slowing sales.

author: Krusher4Lyfe
body:
Not OP, but I’ve never gotten a payout from such low IV. ORCL and CRWD (I think) got me in the past for decent losses. 

I bought one of the QCOM options immediately and then sold it like ten minutes later for ten bucks more. 

5.00 in two weeks is a huge move for that stock.

IMO you’d do better selling credit spreads if you want to take advantage of that 85c

author: piggydancer
body:
And OI finished up 14.82% today. 

We have found the Oracle of Idiocracy!

author: water_boat
body: ORCL products dominate the finance and banking industry from my knowledge. Within the past year, I've dealt with Oracle PeopleSoft, Oracle Hyperion, Sun micro Systems and was offered a job a Strategic Consultant position for NetSuite integration which are all Oracle products.

author: GoldTonight4
body:

i hope you get some fuck

I like Oracle, buying calls today.

author: blazespinnaker
body:
Lot of buyback support at 52 on this stock.   I'd look at it as another CSCO and trade it the same way.

That said, Zoom could surprise to the upside on earnings and potentially push Oracle higher as there was a big deal about Oracle cloud hosting Zoom.

Oracle Cloud is really Oracles only chance to escape the doldrums, but it's not a very good cloud compared to its competitors.

author: QuandlFgt
body:
I work with some huge software vendors, and they've always required Oracle DB in the past, now they all integrate with postgres(free open source database). The free databases are getting so good, a lot of people are questioning why they would go with Oracle for new products. 

It's also one of the first things people are looking to cut with new projects because the licensing fees are so eye watering; like it's legit a few million for Oracle or free postgres. IDK if their cloud is doing well, I've heard it's nice but everyone seems to already be pretty happy with AWS or Azure

author: cough_cough_harrumph
body: Seems the volume is super low for ORCL... what strike were you looking at? I can't find anything that doesn't make me nervous.

author: numbhallow
body: Oh that makes sense, yeah Oracle is the option.  The spread is wide option for sure.

author: imgram
body: Buffet is intelligent and nuanced. Individuals who latch onto PE then pretend like they are the second coming of the Oracle of Omaha are not.

author: det_frank_pembleton
body: Fair enough. I'm not on that side of it, I think we use SAP idk if that's their own software or Oracle under the hood

author: det_frank_pembleton
body: Genuine q: Who uses Oracle? We generally use postgres or AWS for data solutions. I don't think I've even touched an oracle product since we moved from vms to docker.
